conclusion: The problem involves analyzing a collision scenario between Cars A and B based on their velocity-time graphs.
The velocity-time graph shows Car A starting at 25 m/s and decelerating linearly to 0 m/s at t = 25 s, and Car B starting at 15 m/s and decelerating linearly to 0 m/s at t = 30 s.
Both cars begin braking at t = 0 s when they hear the siren.
For a collision to occur, the cars must be at the same position at the same time.
The graph shows that the cars have the same velocity at t = 20 s.
Having the same velocity at t = 20 s does not necessarily mean they collide at that moment; it only means they are traveling at the same speed.
To determine when they collide, we need to find when their positions are equal.
The position function for Car A is derived as xA(t) = xA₀ + 25t - 0.5t².
The position function for Car B is derived as xB(t) = xB₀ + 15t - 0.25t².
Equating the position functions gives xB₀ - xA₀ = 10t - 0.25t², where d = xB₀ - xA₀ is the initial distance between the cars.
For the cars to have just avoided colliding, there must be a specific value of d where they would have barely touched.
Differentiating 10t - 0.25t² and setting it to zero gives t = 20 seconds as the time when the function reaches its maximum value.
At t = 20 seconds, the maximum possible value of d is calculated as d_critical = 100.
If the actual initial distance d is less than 100, the cars will collide, and this will happen at a time different from t = 20 s.
To find the time of collision for d < 100, we solve d = 10t - 0.25t², which has two solutions: one before t = 20 s and one after t = 20 s.
Since Car A starts with a higher speed and decelerates more quickly, it must catch up to Car B from behind.
For a rear-end collision to occur, Car A must still be moving faster than Car B at the moment of collision, which means the collision must happen before t = 20 s.
The two cars collide before 20 seconds of braking because Car A starts with a higher velocity and must catch up to Car B from behind.
